Package sailpoint.workflow

Class StandardWorkflowHandler

  • java.lang.Object
    • sailpoint.workflow.AbstractWorkflowHandler
      • sailpoint.workflow.StandardWorkflowHandler
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    WorkItemHandler, WorkflowHandler
    public class StandardWorkflowHandler
extends AbstractWorkflowHandler
    Default WorkflowHandler for most IdentityIQ workflows. You should not need to replace this but you might want to extend it to add custom handler methods.

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class Description
      static class  StandardWorkflowHandler.EmailArgument
      Constants for WorkflowContext arguments when sending an email.

      • ARG_CATCH_EXCEPTIONS

        public static final java.lang.String ARG_CATCH_EXCEPTIONS
        The original implementations of scheduleEvent and scheduleWorkflowEvent would catch all exceptions andn leave a message in VAR_REQUEST_ERROR that "could be used in transition logic". I don't remember why we ever did this, it doesn't appear to be used and makes it very difficult to see argument errors like missing or invalid workflow names. In 7.0 the behavior was changed to throw exceptions like all the other library methods, on the off chance that someone did have a customication that used this, you will have to pass this argument to restore the old behavior.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • VAR_TASK_LAUNCH_ERROR

        public static final java.lang.String VAR_TASK_LAUNCH_ERROR
        Workflow attribute that holds the error from launchTask(WorkflowContext). See ARG_CATCH_EXCEPTIONS, in 7.0 that must now be passed in order for us to prevent throwing and setting this variable.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • VAR_REQUEST_ERROR

        public static final java.lang.String VAR_REQUEST_ERROR

        Constant Field Values

      • VAR_SCHEDULED_REQUESTS

        public static final java.lang.String VAR_SCHEDULED_REQUESTS
        Workflow variable where we maintain a list of the ids of Requests scheduled during the case. This is mostly for testing so we can get a handle on Requests and wait for them to complete.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • ARG_COMMIT_CREATOR

        public static final java.lang.String ARG_COMMIT_CREATOR
        The name to be used as the "creator" of a BundleArchive. If not set it defaults to the case launcher.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • ARG_COMMIT_ARCHIVE

        public static final java.lang.String ARG_COMMIT_ARCHIVE
        True to create an archive of the current object before saving the new object. There are two possible default values. For simple editing workflows the default is true. For rollback workflows the default is false.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • startWorkflow

        public void startWorkflow​(WorkflowContext wfc)
                   throws GeneralException
        Start process monitoring for the workflow. Prints trace information to stdout if trace is enabled. Extend to add custom behavior. Called when the WorkflowCase starts. Possible use as a hook to setup workflow variables.
        Specified by:
        startWorkflow in interface WorkflowHandler
        Overrides:
        startWorkflow in class AbstractWorkflowHandler
        Throws:
        GeneralException

      • endWorkflow

        public void endWorkflow​(WorkflowContext wfc)
                 throws GeneralException
        End process monitoring for the workflow. Prints trace information to stdout if trace is enabled. Extend to add custom behavior. Called when the WorkflowCase completes. Possible use as a hook to take action on what happened in the workflow, though you could use a final Step for the same purpose.
        Specified by:
        endWorkflow in interface WorkflowHandler
        Overrides:
        endWorkflow in class AbstractWorkflowHandler

               throws GeneralException
        Start process monitoring for the current step. Prints trace information to stdout if trace is enabled. Extend to add custom behavior. Called as each Step starts. WorkflowContext will have the Step about to start.

        public void endStep​(WorkflowContext wfc)
             throws GeneralException
        End process monitoring for the current step. Prints trace information to stdout if trace is enabled. Extend to add custom behavior. Called as each Step completes. WorkflowContext will have the Step that has just completed.

      • startApproval

        public void startApproval​(WorkflowContext wfc)
                   throws GeneralException
        Start process monitoring for the current approval. Prints trace information to stdout if trace is enabled. Extend to add custom behavior. Called as each Approval starts. WorkflowContext will have the Approval about to start. The owner expressions have already been evaluated and the Approval hierarchy has been refactored if necessary. If this is a leaf Approval, the WorkItem has not yet been generated.
        Specified by:
        startApproval in interface WorkflowHandler
        Overrides:
        startApproval in class AbstractWorkflowHandler
        Throws:
        GeneralException

      • endApproval

        public void endApproval​(WorkflowContext wfc)
                 throws GeneralException
        End process monitoring for the current approval. Prints trace information to stdout if trace is enabled. Extend to add custom behavior. Called as each Approval completes. WorkflowContext will have the Approval that has just completed. This is perhaps the most useful callback, it can be used with the "poll" modes to take incremental action as approvals are approved or rejected.
        Specified by:
        endApproval in interface WorkflowHandler
        Overrides:
        endApproval in class AbstractWorkflowHandler
        Throws:
        GeneralException

      • backgroundStep

        public void backgroundStep​(WorkflowContext wfc)
                    throws GeneralException
        Prints trace information to stdout if trace is enabled. Extend to add custom behavior. Called if we reach a step that forces the workflow case into the background. The step has not been officially started yet, it will be advanced when the case resumes in another thread.
        Specified by:
        backgroundStep in interface WorkflowHandler
        Overrides:
        backgroundStep in class AbstractWorkflowHandler
        Throws:
        GeneralException

      • getProperty

        public java.lang.Object getProperty​(WorkflowContext wfc)
        Return the value of a system property. ARG_NAME has the name of the property.

      • isProperty

        public java.lang.Object isProperty​(WorkflowContext wfc)
        Return true if the property has a value. ARG_NAME has the name of the property.

      • getMessage

        public java.lang.Object getMessage​(WorkflowContext wfc)
        Construct a Message from the arguments. ARG_MESSAGE may either be a String or a pre-constructed Message object. If the message is a string, it can either be a message key or literal text. Literal text is allowed to contain the $() pattern to reference workflow variables and step arguments. For example: If the message is a catalog key: Then the the step arguments with names of the form "arg" where is an integer will be passed as arguments to the message renderer ordered by their number. ARG_TYPE can be passed to specify the severity of the message. It is expected to be the string representation of a sailpoint.tools.Message.Type. By default it will be Message.Type.Info.

      • addMessage

        public java.lang.Object addMessage​(WorkflowContext wfc)
        Add a mesasge to the case. Uses getMessage(WorkflowContext) to construct the message. Case messages will be returned in the WorkflowLaunch object when the case is launched. UIs are expected to display the messages. This gives the workflow control over what to show in the UI after launch, for example, "Identity change being approved" or "Identity being provisioned". The Message object is returned though that is not usually useful.

      • addLaunchMessage

        public java.lang.Object addLaunchMessage​(WorkflowContext wfc)
        Add a message to the WorkflowLaunch. This can be only be used when the workflow is launched for the first time before it suspends on an approval. It is intended to let the workflow format a message to be displayed in the UI immediately after the launch that does not have to also be stored in the workflow case. If this is not called, then the default behavior is to display all case messages. You use this for messages like "Request has been submitted" or "Request is being approved by Foo" that the launcher needs to see, but which do not need to be kept in the task result forever like normal case messages.

      • setLaunchMessage

        public java.lang.Object setLaunchMessage​(WorkflowContext wfc)
        Set the workflow launch message. See addLaunchMesasge for more about what launch messages do. This is used in cases where a previous launch message might have been set but we now want to replace it based on the new state of the workflow.

      • log

        public java.lang.Object log​(WorkflowContext wfc)
        Send something to log4j. You will need to enable trace for sailpoint.WorkflowTrace. The default level is "info". ARG_MESSAGE has the text and ARG_LOG_LEVEL has the level: debug, trace, warn, error.

      • print

        public java.lang.Object print​(WorkflowContext wfc)
        Print something to the console. An alternative to logging if you do not want to mess with log4j2.properties. ARG_MESSAGE has the text.

      • audit

        public java.lang.Object audit​(WorkflowContext wfc)
        Create an audit event. These arguments are expected:
        • ARG_AUDIT_SOURCE
        • ARG_AUDIT_ACTION
        • ARG_AUDIT_TARGET
        • ARG_AUDIT_STRING1
        • ARG_AUDIT_STRING2
        • ARG_AUDIT_STRING3
        • ARG_AUDIT_STRING4

      • sendEmail

        public java.lang.Object sendEmail​(WorkflowContext wfc)
                           throws GeneralException
        Send an email notification. Expected arguments are in the EmailArgument enumeration. Optional argument named exceptionOnFailure, when true will cause this method to throw an exception when there is a failure sending a message. This method returns a Message object when there was a problem sending the email. The message will be of Type.Warn if it was retryable and Type.Error when there was an failure that will not be retried. On success the Message object will be null.
        Parameters:
        wfc - Current WorkflowContext
        Returns:
        Message containing the results of attempting to send an e-mail
        Throws:
        GeneralException

      • sendMultipleNotifications

        public java.lang.Object sendMultipleNotifications​(WorkflowContext wfc)
                                           throws GeneralException
        This is similar to the sendEmail method except that it processes multiple notifications at once so it can be called from a single step
        Parameters:
        wfc - Current WorkflowContext
        Returns:
        List containing the results of attempting to send the e-mails
        Throws:
        GeneralException
        See Also:
        "#sendEmail(WorkflowContext)"

      • launchTask

        public java.lang.Object launchTask​(WorkflowContext wfc)
                            throws GeneralException
        Launch a task. 
         Arguments:
   taskDefinition - required name of the TaskDefinition to launch
   taskResult - optional name of the TaskResult
   sync - "true" to request synchronous execution
   * - all other args passed as task launch arguments

 Returns:
   TaskResult

 Sets:
   taskLaunchError - null or a Message object
        The workflow variable taskLaunchError is set as a side effect for use in transition conditions. It will be null if the task was launched successfully or a Message object if the launch failed. NOTE: This, scheduleEvent and scheduleWorkflowEvent has a weird thing where they would catch exceptions and leave a Message in a workflow variable for "testing in transition logic". That doesn't appear to be used, and makes it very difficult to see when you did something wrong, like use an invalid task or workflow name. In 7.0 we now throw like all other library methods, if you want the old behavior you must pass ARG_CATCH_EXCEPTIONS.
        Throws:
        GeneralException

      • scheduleRequest

        public java.lang.Object scheduleRequest​(WorkflowContext wfc)
                                 throws GeneralException
        Launch a generic event request. 
         Arguments:

   requestDefinition
     - required name of the RequestDefinition to launch

   requestName
     - name you want to give the request

   scheduleDate
     - date at which to perform request, if not specified request
       is processed on the next request manager cycle

   scheduleDelaySeconds
     - alternate to date, the number of seconds after the
       current time to schedule the event

   launcher
     - name considered to be the source of the request
       defaults to Workflow launcher if not specified

   owner
     - identity to be considered the owner of this request
       used for "event" requsts
   *
     - all other args passed as request arguments

 Sets:
   requestError - null or a Message object
        The workflow variable requestError is set as a side effect for use in transition conditions. It will be null if the task was launched successfully or a Message object if the launch failed. NOTE: This and scheduleWorkflowEvent had a weird thing where they would catch exceptions and leave a Messsage in the "requestError" variable. That's of dubious merit and I don't think has evern been used. In 7.0 this throws exceptions like all the other methods so you can see what went wrong. On the off chance that someone actually wanted the old behavior they must pass ARG_CATCH_EXCEPTIONS.
        Throws:
        GeneralException

      • scheduleWorkflowEvent

        public java.lang.Object scheduleWorkflowEvent​(WorkflowContext wfc)
                                       throws GeneralException
        Launch a workflow event request. Arguments are the same as those for scheduleEvent except for these: 
         Arguments:

   workflow
     - name of the Workflow to launch

   caseName
     - optional case name to override the default

   requestDefinition
     - not specified, set to standard definition for
       workflow requests

 Sets:
   requestError - null or a Message object
        This is just a wrapper around scheduleRequest specifying the stock RequestDefinition for workflow events and validating the extra arguments. NOTE: This and scheduleEvent had a weird thing where they would catch exceptions and leave a Messsage in the "requestError" variable. That's of dubious merit and I don't think has evern been used. In 7.0 this throws exceptions like all the other methods so you can see what went wrong. On the off chance that someone actually wanted the old behavior they must pass ARG_CATCH_EXCEPTIONS.
        Throws:
        GeneralException

      • commit

        public java.lang.Object commit​(WorkflowContext wfc)
                        throws GeneralException
        Commit an object stored within the workflow case to the database, typically after an approval step. There are two variants of this, one that commits changes to an object, and one that commits the deletion of an object. This is where role archives are created. Archival must be requested by passing the "doArchive" argument. This is normally defined as a configuration variable in the Workflow. Arguments recognized:
        • ARG_COMMIT_ARCHIVE
        • ARG_COMMIT_CREATOR
        Throws:
        GeneralException

      • rollback

        public java.lang.Object rollback​(WorkflowContext wfc)
                          throws GeneralException
        Rollback a change to an object held in the workflow. This is not technically a rollback since the changes were never persisted in the first place. What we do however is remove the linkage between the object being edited and the workflow case so it becomes "unlocked" and can be edited again.
        Throws:
        GeneralException

      • getMessage

        public static java.lang.String getMessage​(java.lang.String key,
                                          java.lang.Object arg)
        Localize a message.

      • getStringList

        protected static java.util.List<java.lang.String> getStringList​(java.lang.Object value)
        Coerce the given value into a list of strings. The value of the selections argument can be one of: - String - List Further, each String can be a CSV.
